is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': "Icon Awards Marc Lutz//September 21, 2023// Trinity Health CEO Bolano to step down Odette Bolano will retire from her position as president and CEO of Trinity Health West Region's Saint Alphonsus and Saint Agnes health systems in June 2024. Marc Lutz//September 21, 2023// A long and active career in health care is coming to a close. Trinity Health West Region Chief Executive Officer Odette C. Bolano has announced she will retire in June of 2024. Bolano was the first CEO of Trinity’s West Region, uniting Saint Alphonsus in Idaho and Oregon with California-based Saint Agnes Medical Center. She has been president and CEO for the past five years. She has served for eight years in an executive leadership role for Saint Alphonsus. “Odette leaves a lasting mark on the communities served by Saint Alphonsus and Saint Agnes and our national health system,” said Ben Carter, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Livonia, Michigan-based Trinity Health. “Her passion and commitment to high-quality, safe care has been nationally recognized and truly embodies our mission,” Carter continued in a statement. “I know all of Trinity Health shares my heartfelt appreciation for all Odette has accomplished.” During Bolano’s leadership at Trinity, Saint Alphonsus was named as one of the country’s top 15 health systems by IBM Watson and recognized by U.S. News & World Report. Under her purview, Saint Alphonsus opened Idaho’s first advanced neuro, surgical and trauma intensive care unit last year. Outside of her work in the health care industry, Bolano serves as chair-elect of the Idaho Hospital Association, chair of the Boise Metro Chamber of Commerce and Boise State University Foundation, among others. Additionally, she is a member of the Carol Emmott Fellowship board, which is a national organization that mentors women leaders in the health care industry. Along with her other board memberships, Bolano serves on the board of the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation and on the board for Idaho Power/IDACORP. She was Idaho Business Review’s Woman of the Year in 2021 and was recognized by Modern Healthcare as one of the 50 most influential clinical executives in health care and twice as one of the top 25 women executives in health care. Her most recently accolade was being named one of the “Top 100 Most Influential People in Healthcare.” The search to find Bolano’s replacement will begin in January next year. Trinity Health West Region Chief Executive Officer Odette C. Bolano has announced she will retire in June of 2024. Bolano was the first CEO of Trinity’s West Region, uniting Saint Alphonsus in Idaho and Oregon with California-based Saint Agnes Medical Center. She has been president and CEO for the past five years. She has served for eight years in an executive leadership role for Saint Alphonsus. “Odette leaves a lasting mark on the communities served by Saint Alphonsus and Saint Agnes and our national health system,” said Ben Carter, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Livonia, Michigan-based Trinity Health. “Her passion and commitment to high-quality, safe care has been nationally recognized and truly embodies our mission,” Carter continued in a statement. “I know all of Trinity Health shares my heartfelt appreciation for all Odette has accomplished.” During Bolano’s leadership at Trinity, Saint Alphonsus was named as one of the country’s top 15 health systems by IBM Watson and recognized by U.S. News & World Report. Under her purview, Saint Alphonsus opened Idaho’s first advanced neuro, surgical and trauma intensive care unit last year. Outside of her work in the health care industry, Bolano serves as chair-elect of the Idaho Hospital Association, chair of the Boise Metro Chamber of Commerce and Boise State University Foundation, among others. Additionally, she is a member of the Carol Emmott Fellowship board, which is a national organization that mentors women leaders in the health care industry. Along with her other board memberships, Bolano serves on the board of the American Board of Internal Medicine Foundation and on the board for Idaho Power/IDACORP. She was Idaho Business Review’s Woman of the Year in 2021 and was recognized by Modern Healthcare as one of the 50 most influential clinical executives in health care and twice as one of the top 25 women executives in health care. Her most recently accolade was being named one of the “Top 100 Most Influential People in Healthcare.” The search to find Bolano’s replacement will begin in January next year. confident that the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'In May 2023, one of the most widespread cybercriminal organizations known as CLOP (or TA505) utilized a SQL injection vulnerability to interfere with MOVEit Transfer software, which is connected to countless databases of company information. This Russian group of hackers encrypted a web shell nicknamed LEMURLOOT into the network of MOVEit, using it as a backdoor to infiltrate the web application and extract data.. Welcome to the era of cybercrime. “We have this pop culture perspective that’s been given to us by various avenues that hackers work alone,” Edward Vasko, the Director for Institute for Pervasive Cybersecurity, said. “They’re individuals that are nefarious and so forth. The reality is it’s very organized, it’s very structured. And it actually leverages well known business models to conduct criminal activity.” This massive data breach has been underway for the last couple of months, affecting 3,000 U.S organizations and 8,000 global organizations, according to the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Agency (CSA). The list of targeted businesses and major companies include everything from US banks like First National Bankers Bank, to oil giants like Shell and the well-known educational nonprofit National Student Clearinghouse. The US Department of Energy, Shutterfly.com, American Airlines, Warner Bros and even the University of Idaho systems have been attacked. Boise State University was targeted as well, and students and faculty were notified in an email sent out July 14, 2023, at 4:14 p.m. National Student Clearinghouse alerted Boise State of the breach through MOVEit Transfer, the system they use for filing information, according to the email sent out by the Registrar Office. “Boise State learned that personally identifiable information about some students was compromised as a result of the worldwide data breach,” the email stated. The good news is that Boise State systems are not at risk, just the information linked to the third party MOVEit Transfer software. Regardless, Boise State is in contact with the Idaho State Board of Education to oversee the situation as it progresses. The landing page Boise State provided for updates said, “We believe some students and employees will receive letters in the mail advising that information you shared with Boise State and our vendors may have been compromised.” Director of Media Relations, Mike Sharp, told The Arbiter in an email, “Boise State University was notified by the National Student Clearinghouse that July’s data breach affected sensitive information of three unenrolled Boise State students.” Clearinghouse will contact the impacted students and information such as names, email addresses, etc. of other students may have been exposed as well. “Boise State University continues to work with the Clearinghouse as they address their response to the MoveIt breach. A campus update is forthcoming,” Sharp wrote. So what exactly happened? CLOP’s strategy of cybercrime is tied to ransomware, a type of malware that blocks a web system and demands money in return to reboot up the system, remove a virus or a bug, or return stolen information. It’s blackmailing, and CLOP has been around the block a few times when it comes to demanding money in return for recovering company information. CLOP historically will discover a zero-day flaw in a system, exploit that flaw, extract data and then send a ransom note to whatever company they target. In ransom notes, CLOP threatens to publish or sell all vulnerable information on the black market if their victims do not comply. Viruses and phishing scams emerged in the 1990’s alongside a new virtual reality. Since the beginning of the internet, cybercrime has existed, not for an era, but for thirty years give or take. It’s no secret that even sharing information on social media platforms is taking a calculated risk. Accounts can be hacked into from Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat, Twitter, Facebook and more. People can fake profile identities, scam users, engage in sextortion and commit other cyber crimes on social media, like trafficking, dm phishing and catfishing. “I think the important thing to keep in mind is that these platforms are collecting information, they are receiving information from you that could be inappropriately leveraged,” Vasko said. Living in a digital universe means that there will always be the danger of the dark web, malware, hackers and cybercrime. Save my name, email, and website in this browser for the next time I comment. Δ Editor-in-Chief Hanalei Potempa | editor@stumedia.boisestate.edu Online Editor Adam Bridges | onlineeditor@stumedia.boisestate.edu Arbiter Staff: (208)-426-6308 Sales Team: (208)-426-6302 The Arbiter is the official independent student news source of Boise State, where student editors make all content decisions and bear responsibility for those decisions. The Arbiter’s budget consists of fees paid by the student body and advertising sales.'}]

'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Subscribe Emmett residents had an opportunity Wednesday, Dec. 6 to see first-hand what the Idaho Transportation Department currently has in mind for future improvements to the traffic flow between Emmett and the Treasure Valley. The drop-in at Emmett High drew over 400 people to see, hear, and ask questions of ITD representatives and officials from the City of Emmett and Gem County. Most of those attending focused their attention on a layout of maps in the center of the High School atrium that detailed different segments of the 16 miles stretching of SH-16 from SH-44 to the intersection with SH-52 at Washington Avenue in Emmett. The meeting was the second public meeting last week to provide residents from both ends of the busily traveled highway a look at what work has been done to this point and what the process is before construction can begin in future years. A meeting in Eagle on Dec. 4 mirrored the Emmett meeting. “State Highway 16 is a key transportation corridor in the central Treasure Valley,” said ITD Project Manager Mark Wasdahl. “This environmental document is the next important step toward addressing long-term safety and traffic capacity. We are asking for the community’s feedback at several points in this process.” ITD began the process in June, building on a previous environmental assessment first completed in 2004. Since then they have been reevaluating traffic flows and patterns, access controls, safety studies, and resource assessments. The progress they have made on that study was what was on display in Emmett last week. The mapping of the entire length of the assessment area included specific suggested alternatives at different segments of the route where current or pending projects could or would make an impact on future traffic flow. ITD points to changes since the 2004 study, particularly population growth, an increase in traffic and development, and an increase in crashes and the severity of crashes as the factors requiring an update and reassessment process. The plans discussed nearly two decades ago were used as a basis to begin the discussion of design options as new data was integrated into the process. With construction underway on a connection of SH-16 from its current terminus at SH-20/26 to a new exchange at I-84, ITD is keenly aware of impacts that may have on the northern end of SH-16. In 2005 ITD’s completed assessment received Federal approval to: Each of those elements are included in the current discussion as well, though some alternatives have already been ruled out due to changes in conditions since 2005. Development since 2005, particularly at the southern end of the assessment area, and the marked increase in accidents along the corridor have influenced some of those decisions. ITD data shows that between 2007-2011 there were 152 crashes on SH-16. Between 2017-2021 there were 288 crashes, The northern end of the assessment area appeared to be of greatest interest to those in attendance at the Emmett meeting. What plans are being contemplated to improve the safety and flow of traffic on the Freezeout grade, and how would that impact the current access points at the bottom of the grade? The grade issue is perhaps the biggest engineering obstacle to be considered in the plan. Most actual engineering will not begin until this environmental assessment has been completed — likely the summer of 2025. Widening the Freezeout grade to four lanes — divided or undivided — will require considerable fill at several locations. That fill would have to be of a structural material to be hauled in as the sandy composition of the immediate hillsides are unlikely to provide a sustainable base for a widened roadbed. The total expanded width needed will be determined by the choice of lane plans. Some local officials proposed a three-lane design — two lanes up and a single lane down — as a perhaps most cost-effective way to facilitate a quicker solution. Those remarks directly related to the significant growth in heavy truck traffic going up the grade each day, a factor in slowdowns and traffic backups. Cherry Lane Access Preliminary design plans presented by ITD at the meeting and in its online material, offer two suggested ways to handle the Cherry Lane access at SH-16. One modification would be to go ahead with a full interchange as appeared in the 2005 plans. The second modification alternative referred to in ITD illustrations as Modification 1, would call for an at-grade intersection of Cherry and SH-16 but will restrict access to right turn in and out at Cherry Lane. A local access road underpass south of Cherry Lane would be added with the widening of the Freeze Out grade, Many of those in attendance at the Emmett meeting expressed surprise at the illustration of a large subdivision on the east side of SH-16 at Cherry Lane. ITD said that the underlying subdivision map was for illustrative purposes and though freshly drawn, it was based on a proposal in place in 2004. Despite the concerns voiced at the meeting, there is no currently approved subdivision on that property. “There was a proposed subdivision back in 2006 when it was annexed into the City of Emmett back then,” explained Jennifer Kharll, Planning Director for Gem County. “When the Little’s (David and Adam) took ownership they de-annexed the property to run cattle on the land. If what the map showed is in the plans, it isn’t anything the County has seen and it wouldn’t be approved in the County at that density since that property is zoned A-2 and R-2. There would have to be an annexation application filed with the City then the subdivision applications with the City.” No such application has been filed with the City according to City officials and David Little confirmed no annexation application has been filed with the City. “Concept plans similar to the 2004 proposal that include a new two-lane bridge that would move traffic off of the one lane bridge at E. 12th St. bridge is being looked at to understand the traffic impacts.” Little said. “Potatoes will be grown on the land in 2024 and the land is not for sale.” For illustrative purposes, Messenger Index has removed that subdivision from the two maps included with this story so that the theoretic traffic patterns of each modification option would be more discernable. Two other properties that could potentially be directly impacted by the plans would be the Sandy Sanders property on the northeast corner and the Packing Shed event center on the southwest corner of the interchange. Sanders remarked at the Wednesday meeting that “ITD talked about these ideas twenty years. I’m still listening. I have had no direct conversations with ITD to this point.” Substation to Mill Road Design plans for SH-16 from Substation to Washington Avenue calls for four lanes with center turn lane and/or painted median. While this assessment process does not include the segment of SH-52 to goes west from Washington Avenue, ITD officials have confirmed that they are currently moving forward for a possible installation of a signal light at SH-52 and Mill Road, pending funding in next fiscal year. Community Input Sought “We have looked forward to sharing the range of modified improvement plans with the communities and receiving their feedback,” said Wasdahl. “The community input is very important to the reevaluation process and will help us moving forward.” ITD is continuing to seek community input, through December 21. You can access the interactive maps and take a tour of each section of the highway corridor at https://tinyurl.com/2p84s6yh. There is an access point in the later portion of this presentation that allows the viewer to log their comments concerning each specific segment. ITD is also taking emails regarding the project at this point at sh16@itd.idaho.gov. Only comments placed in person at the public meetings, input online or provided through email will be included in the official records of the assessment process. Facebook and local social media posts will not be accumulated or entered in the official record.
